body:
> We could rebase on cnd to build against JDK21ga (now in cnd)

CI is only building the `full` cluster config and cnd isn't part of it atm. So it doesn't matter for now what the build does. It all depends what the next steps are. We could setup a job which builds CND separately or ignore CI and wait till its part of the full cluster.

Let me know if you need anything.
FWIW, a few weeks ago, I was experimenting with "merging" CND and cpplite. I'll need to adjust that to this merge and finish, but it is unlikely I'd have time for that in the next ~2 weeks.

> We could setup a job which builds CND separately or ignore CI and wait till its part of the full cluster.

That seems like a decent reason to merge cnd into master.  I seem to be able to have cpplite and cnd coexist peacefully enough for development by disabling one or the other module, but I'm pretty clueless.  We would probably not want to release netbeans with CND and cpplite at this point, but having both requiring someone to choose one to enable seems fine for development if I'm not missing some terrible side effects of this configuration.

> My only concern is that if we intend to bring back cnd.navigation some day, this will be redundant. Is cnd.navigation shunned for good?

I think it's important to understand that accepting this pull request is effectively pounding some nails in cnd.navigation's coffin and maybe we don't want to do that.  Not understanding why it was mothballed leaves me unsure of the path forward for bringing back features the cnd modules that now live in contrib provide.  There are lots of alternatives to what I did in this pull request which is akin to haphazardly copy/pasting the feature from cnd.navigation into the somewhat arbitrary cnd.editor module.

Here are two other things that are important enough to me that I'd like to try to do something about them soon-ish (there are many other useful features in contrib/cnd.*):
* the 'Go to Declaration/Implementation' feature provided by cnd.completion
* cnd.discovery is needed to create a new "C/C++ Project with Existing Sources".
  * The current state of this feature in cnd is broken.  The wizard fails because the DiscoveryExtension class in cnd.discovery is a service provider for the IteratorExtension.class that is needed to finalize/save the project.  cnd.discovery needs cnd/cnd.discovery/external/cnd-build-trace-1.0.zip native binaries as noted in [jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-5486).  Based on the disposition of that ticket, I assume that's hopeless effectively killing cnd.discovery.  Do we need to devise some simpler alternative  to the vast array of complex capabilities cnd.discovery has for creating a C/C++ project from existing sources?
Hi I have opened a pull request referencing this issue, but I require some guidance. Can someone please review and help me with it?

> > We could rebase on cnd to build against JDK21ga (now in cnd)
> 
> CI is only building the `full` cluster config and cnd isn't part of it atm. So it doesn't matter for now what the build does. It all depends what the next steps are. We could setup a job which builds CND separately or ignore CI and wait till its part of the full cluster.
> 
> Let me know if you need anything.

D'oh! I thought we had cnd in the full cluster on this branch. Too bad we don't. We could remove cpplite and add cnd instead.
Changes look perfect. Let's merge.
I noticed this too at work, but did not have time to investigate. Thanks for doing what I should have done @mbien and thank you for looking into this @sdedic.

For me, this issue is about using netbeans for jfx/rcp development. Netbeans has worked on a bundled JDK/JFX in the past, and a change in netbeans broke things just after version 113.

Maybe the change that is needed is to document that this is no longer a supported configuration?

I am used to using the bundled jfx, so the next step in this for me is to re package my rcp projects to use jfx in a netbeans module, rather than having the ide run it, which is probably a better approach overall and will most likely fix the issue. 

Another possibility would be to include a module which calls the jfx function Platform.exit() in the IDE on shutdown which I will play around with.

interesting that this isn't reproducible when started from NB. This reminds me however that we have to rename that category into "Dukescript Applications" or something similar, to be less ambiguous. (added #6551)
I tried some of the options of the wizard (e.g "Run in a browser") and the priming build did fail, not sure if its still under active development https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.dukescript.api
It the wizard renders the checkboxes in a non standard way (its a JFXPanel, so I suppose its a JavaFX bridge for rendering 4 checkboxes with html).

I don't like the solution - while it hides opening brace, it shows the paired one. In addition, folding itself is not blocked entirely - one can do CTRL+ plus near the folded part to unfold. 

So the really buggy thing is just the indicator (appearance) and its handling.

I would suggest to add a different indicator in this case, to signal that both operations are possible. In addition, if the expand sign handler just gives a preference to "expand" (now it prefers collapse, if there are more options on the same line), it could be satisfactory.  If not, then I suggest to enhance the handler so that it recognizes some modifier (shift ?) and od expand or collapse, depending on it.

I've just briefly checked IntelliJ and vscode.
- IntelliJ shows just "expand" marker if there are both collapsed and expanded fold regions on the line. Clicking it expands the 1st folded region
- vscode leaves BOTH {} visible, replaces just the content.

I'd prefer the IntelliJ way :)

@sdedic yeah I had similar thoughts here https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/6504#issuecomment-1741878426, I think that when the expand action is given higher priority than collapse, most of this issue is already avoided.

I would like not to do the shift indicator because we can use it for another type of collapsing/expanding. In VS Code or IntelliJ u can use shift + alt to expand/collapse everything else except from that where you clicked on. So expand/collapse should be a normal operation with one click and nothing else as in all  editors. There is no need to use another key to just handle this normal behaviour.

For IntelliJ there is one more thing to know, that they have also an indicator to expand/collapse on the closing bracket which seems also need if you have long code parts.

For me i prefer the VS Code way to not include the braces into the fold state. So maybe an option is better than some hardcoded stuff as you can see, we have different preferences. And if we can't find the best way, I'm for an option.

For the IntelliJ way, I do need to know how to handle that and folding everything for example if/else if/else is only possible with the new indicator at the position of the closing bracket.

Or we can do it in a mixed way. Using both good parts from both IDEs.
I also need to say that IntelliJ with the legacy UI has this feature, the new UI has an arrow similar to vs code.

code folding to me is a visual aid to collapse lines of code vertically to parse code faster in some situations.
collapsing a try-catch with 3 catches becomes this in NB 19:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/2dbb2893-57de-4fc4-9243-e68fafd0d036)

With this patch applied we get this:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/243f24f7-41f2-4552-9f1c-ff9b21eb53e2)

all visual arguments aside (if it should show brackets in the placeholder or not), one of the two behaviors is useful the other is not in my opinion :)
@mbien pushed

I cannot reproduce @matthiasblaesing issue with NB19 and a clean userdir.  Haven't tested with a build from master or this PR yet.  That wizard has always been a bit flaky with ergonomics, and caused a bunch of historic problems (release blockers, etc.).  Still, it does seem OK on the last release for me. 

Mind you, blank is also normal on my working install - I refuse to install JavaFX modules solely to show a dialog that I don't need, with incongruous UI, that breaks 50% of the time, and needlessly uses 3 UI toolkits! :wink:

I'm still in favour of removing the html4j wizard support from the platform entirely.

> I don't think you are right with this. I can clearly see the maven command at the beginning of the output window and this says mvn pre-integration-test failsafe:integration-test What would you expect as maven command for an integration test?

@sroeper that!  This changed in NB14 with #4096 The Test Results UI was reported as working above in NB13 or earlier - eg. _when the integration test was being run as a unit test_.

Revert is not a good solution: the thrown exception suggests that the execution (somehow) bypassed all the checks for `RepositorySession.isOffline()` or the session was misconfigured NOT to be offline.

The previous impl just hid / swallowed the error condition, most probably.

i mean I have nothing against removing the dukescript pieces. If the embedded browser isn't used anywhere it might even allow NB to drop bundled javafx (which is a fairly large dependency).

The main reason I renamed it was because I end up in that wizard from time to time by accident, then realizing that its clearly not what I expected it to be.

thanks for taking a look -> merging

thanks for the review! I did look at the reflection snippet at first but didn't want to change too much here (I also don't have much experience with the javac API), the code is copied from the TreeShims class almost unmodified.

> NB to drop bundled javafx (which is a fairly large dependency).

Well, we don't bundle it, and the web view we never could as it's LGPL.  All uses need to remain optional, so this wizard should really drop back to displaying something useful when its dependency cannot be met.  Still, discussion for elsewhere.

Thanks for the change.  Have had multiple discussions with end users ending up in that wizard also by accident!

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/1c9eeab4ace3fa27517a2e1df246377e9fdf9115/ergonomics/ide.ergonomics/src/org/netbeans/modules/ide/ergonomics/newproject/DescriptionStep.java#L274-L283

So it is throwing it only when assertions are enabled. Might be a timeout, or something worse. This area would need much more refactoring. I mostly only removed dead code here and simplified parts.

But when I go through the steps @matthiasblaesing posted, when I open the duke script wizard for the first time it remains empty for 3-4s. So it does take fairly long till something happens.

If I open it right away, as first step with fresh config, i see this for about 1s before it goes away to the next panel (there is nothing i can press):
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/437eb95f-3335-4c52-b083-c53159a793fd)

Which would be another UI panel with broken layout (i test on linux btw and it has a checkbox for windows checked)

So, I can't reproduce the issue Matthias is experiencing. (I tried offline too)

Using either `Team / Git / Open Global Configuration` or `Team / Repository / Open Global Configuration` depending on context, and add

```
[init]
	defaultBranch = yoda
```

Hm. So not only unconfigured session. Maven's `DefaultLegacySupport` contains a thread-local variable that holds the current `RepositorySession` (through MavenSession). If the "offline" execution happened to be planned on a thread that formerly used "online" embedder, the online session remained in the thread local - and was used instead.

The new commit in this patch replaces the current value with the appropriate one, configured for the executing Embedder; this does not affect other threads (if they use also Maven libraries), as it is replaced in a thread-local variable.

@mbien -- Please test from this PR's branch. There's a Maven patch attached, against `maven-3.9.5` tag. As a convenience, I've attached built binaries - to be replaced in `java/maven/lib`. All that is zipped into the attachment.

[maven-patches.zip](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/12868734/maven-patches.zip)

Trying to build a gradle project that uses the spotbugs plugin in Netbeans makes Netbeans fail the build with an empty message error and mark the project as unloadable and fallbacking to Java 5 (yikes!).

Netbeans 19 (but it also happened in older versions)
Java 21 (but I also tested with 20)
Gradle 8.4 (but I also tested with 8.3)
Spotbugs gradle plugin 6.0.0-beta4
Spotbugs 4.7.3

Since it runs perfectly when running Gradle on CMD an it only goes nuts in Netbeans, It fails to load giving a blank error message and fallbacks to Java 5 (a very unfortunate choice for a fallback, since this spuriously makes about everything in the code being marked as an error).

I created a minimal Hello World with a minimal gradle with spotbugs file to show the problem: https://github.com/victorwss/min-spotbugs-gradle

It seems that as soon as I add `id("com.github.spotbugs") version "6.0.0-beta.4"` in the gradle build script, Netbeans go nuts.

Running it in the console:

```
C:\Projects\min-spotbugs-gradle>gradle build

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 657ms
6 actionable tasks: 6 up-to-date
C:\Projects\min-spotbugs-gradle>gradle run

> Task :run
Hello World

BUILD SUCCESSFUL in 732ms
2 actionable tasks: 1 executed, 1 up-to-date
```

Opening it in Netbeans 19:

![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/4574568/5ed6394c-5292-4e3e-9bfa-8933129d1815)
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/4574568/1f9bc72a-78c3-4443-b261-1417579e6ac5)

I don't know for sure about other plugins, but I think that the cause is the same.

Thanks @matthiasblaesing I would remove the `r` from the parent folder name instead, and keep the filename from the vote - it's in the subject line.  I think we'll be fine using `1-<hash>`, `2-<hash>`, etc.

You know there's always `./bin/netbeans --userdir /tmp/foo1` ? :smile:

@roberto-cisternino the JDK is not relevant for this discussion. What you are seeing is the fallout of the situation Oracle and the Eclipse Foundation produced, because they decided to change namespaces. You can play the blame game or get hacking and fix it in NetBeans. There are people working on support for JakartaEE and infrastructure is coming up for it, but contributors have real life, other projects or other reasons not to DONATE more time.

Thanks @eirikbakke Am I right in thinking you made the original of this?  Was there an svg somewhere?

Yes! It was made in Adobe Illustrator, but the following SVG is probably better to keep as an "original" going forward:

![NetBeans HiDPI Splash Screen Template](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/886243/b86ceb97-d43c-45d0-a117-c10353cbc0c4)

The splash screen contains a slightly cleaned-up version of the NetBeans logo, which I have also put in a separate file here:

![Apache NetBeans Logo with Product Name](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/886243/2aec824d-e245-4dc6-a0e3-334400a315af)

The cleanup was just tiny changes of the vertex positions so that adjacent edges don't have microscopic gaps in them (which sometimes cause artifacts when the SVG is rasterized to PNG).

Hi @jhorvath, for future PRs, it would be better to merge from a branch of your clone into the main repo, instead of creating a branch on the main repo. This creates several problems otherwise, it builds and tests everything twice without taking labels into account, increases the [cache](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/caches) usage per branch etc. 
We usually don't create main repo branches for individual PRs, only for long lasting tasks, like CND for example.

don't forget to squash before merge, thanks!

> Hi @jhorvath, for future PRs, it would be better to merge from a branch of your clone into the main repo, instead of creating a branch on the main repo. This creates several problems otherwise, it builds and tests everything twice without taking labels into account, increases the [cache](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/actions/caches) usage per branch etc. We usually don't create main repo branches for individual PRs, only for long lasting tasks, like CND for example.
> 
> don't forget to squash before merge, thanks!

@johbor I guess the `/faces/*` comes from the specifications default: 

> When using prefix mapping, the following mapping is recommended, but not required:
>
> ```
> <servlet-mapping>
>   <servlet-name> faces-servlet-name </servlet-name>
>   <url-pattern> /faces/* </url-pattern>
> </servlet-mapping>
> ```

https://jakarta.ee/specifications/faces/4.0/jakarta-faces-4.0.html#a6076

I guess changing the default would require some more data than "is mostly used".

@asbachb Changing the default mapping to *.xhtml also prevents the discovery of the raw *.xhtml files. If not set this way but to /faces/* one can ask e.g. https://[whatever-domain]/index.xhtml and you get the raw xhtml file. But when you ask for https://[whatever-domain]/faces/index.xhtml you get the faces page as it is meant to be. 
When set to *.xhtml the the https://[whatever-domain]/index.xhtml url delivers the faces page and not the raw xhtml

I had a look at the PR and I think all changes outside `JavaBracesMatcher.java` should not be there. of course you can try to change the lexing strategy for the java language in NetBeans, but that will be an uphill battle. I suggest to modify the braces matcher to deal with situations where characters do not map to a single token.

The java lexer can generate these tokens, that could match your case:

- JavaTokenId.LT
- JavaTokenId.LTLT
- JavaTokenId.LTLTEQ
- JavaTokenId.GT
- JavaTokenId.GTEQ
- JavaTokenId.GTGT
- JavaTokenId.GTGTEQ
- JavaTokenId.GTGTGT
- JavaTokenId.GTGTGTEQ

For example this code:

```java

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.UUID;


public class testLexer<V> {
    public static <K,V2> void add(K k, V2 v) {}

    public static void main(String[] argv) {
        Map<String,Map<UUID,List<Map<Integer,Number>>>> m = new HashMap<>();
    }
}
```

is lexed to this token stream:

```
IMPORT          "import", la=1
WHITESPACE      " ", la=1
IDENTIFIER      "java", la=1
DOT             ".", la=1
IDENTIFIER      "util", la=1
DOT             ".", la=1
IDENTIFIER      "HashMap", la=1
SEMICOLON       ";"

```

The dump was generated by saving the java file to `java/java.lexer/test/unit/data/testfiles/testLexer.java`, adding 

```java
    public void test2() throws Exception {
        LexerTestUtilities.checkTokenDump(this, "testfiles/testLexer.java",
                JavaTokenId.language());
    }
```

to `JavaTokenDumpTest` and running that test.

In the sample you find both `GT` and `GTGTGT`. I don't know _why_ it was done this way, but I would start with the assumption, that they author made a sane decision there.
@mbien A newer version would be better, but there is no problem at the moment, I think :) Thanks for the information!
